name: (2E)-2-[4-(1-Naphthyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-(2-thienyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1246

name: (2E)-2-[4-(1-Naphthyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-(2-thienyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1246
Reason: The target compound has several functional groups that contribute to its melting point: basic unit naphthalene has a melting point of 80.1°C, thiophene rings (two are present) are expected to increase the melting point by approximately +30°C each due to the increased rigidity and planarity they add to the molecule, the acrylonitrile group can add +20°C due to its polar nature and ability to participate in dipole-dipole interactions, and the additional thiazole ring is similar in nature to thiophene but also contains a nitrogen atom, which could allow for hydrogen bonding or dipole interactions adding a further +35°C. The conjugated system throughout the entire molecule contributes to its rigidity, thereby increasing the intermolecular forces and, as a result, the melting point, estimated as an additional +10°C.
Prediction: 205°C (80.1°C for naphthalene + 2 * 30°C for thiophene rings + 20°C for acrylonitrile + 35°C for thiazole + 10°C for the conjugated system)

name: (2E)-2-[4-(1-Naphthyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-(2-thienyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1246
Reason: The target compound has several functional groups influencing its melting point. The basic naphthalene unit has a melting point of 80.1°C. Each of the two thiophene rings contributes an estimated +30°C due to their ability to increase molecular rigidity and planarity. The acrylonitrile group is expected to add approximately +20°C because of its polar nature which facilitates dipole-dipole interactions. The thiazole ring, which is structurally similar to thiophene but also comprises a nitrogen atom, potentially adds around +35°C due to possibilities of hydrogen bonding or dipole interactions. The extensive conjugation across the molecule further raises the melting point; this is attributed an additional value of +10°C because of increased molecular rigidity and stronger intermolecular forces.
